intro: Peristylus wheatleyi, commonly known as the desert bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with hairy stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually blue to purple in color, appearing in clusters at the ends of the stems. Peristylus wheatleyi is adapted to survive in hot, dry environments, with a deep root system that helps it access water from deeper soil layers.
